Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2009 10:32PM - edited Jan 9, 2009 10:34PM by Imasurvivor All of the nails on my hands lifted completely where they were loose all the way back, but a very little on each side stayed attached and held them on.  I clipped them extremely short so I wouldn't catch them and pull them off.  You never know how much you depend on your nails until you don't have them.  I was referred to a dermatologist and he was very laid-back about the situation.  He told me to cover them with dark nail polish and no one would know.  He said if I was a man he would tell me to clip them all the way back, but beings I was a woman, he didn't think I'd like that look.  I don't have time for nail polish so I left them alone.  It was early-December that this all happened.  I have been taking Biotin since October because it was obvious back then that I had a problem - nails were dark and painful.  I did use tea tree oil, to no avail.  They are growing in normally and are already between 1/4 and 1/3 of the way back even though the Dr. said it would take 3 to 6 months.  Nothing happened w/toenails except they are sore.  Dr. said my nails were photosensitive from the chemo.  Makes me wonder if a dark nail polish from the get-go would have saved them.
Posts.Title: Finger/fingernail problems? How common? Texas357 Texas357

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2008 05:54AM Imasurvivor wrote: Don't know what's wrong with me.  I always liked my hair and enjoyed fixing it everyday.  Had tons of stying products, etc.  It starting falling out on day 10 of tx and by day 12 I had to have it shaved.  My beautician felt worse than I did.  It felt like a haircut to me, no sadness.  I must be in denial.  I love my wig but when I get home my head goes nude.
Posts.Title: Wig recommendations? SuzyWillKickThis getwell

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 01:37AM Imasurvivor wrote: I developed a dry cough towards the end of my rads.  I have now had the cough for 3 months and complained to my rad dr. and my oncologist.  They both brushed me off but now my onc did a chest x-ray which was not definitive.  Am scheduled for a visit with a pulmonary specialist on 4/7.  My cough sounds just like yours.  Chronic, dry, and unproductive.  Worse when laying down. I also have been complaining of rib pain on the noncancerous breast side and they have ignored me on that, too.  They are also going to do a bone scan on 4/7.  It will be interesting to see if there is damage to my lungs.  Please let us know what you find out.
Posts.Title: AFTER radiation: lung fibrosis??? Myrajuc Imasurvivor

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 11:38PM Imasurvivor wrote: I worked throughout rads but the fatigue was horrendous.  It started by week 2 and continued through week six.  I can't count the number of times I fell asleep at my desk.  Good thing I work alone and have a doorbell that rings when I get customers!  This week I am just doing my boosts and my energy level feels the closest to normal that it has since I started.  The boosts must not be as hard on me as the other rads were.
Posts.Title: side effects of radiation therapy Maria217 Imasurvivor
